text: in the United States despite the deal to
raise the debt ceiling markets today
fear that not enough has been done to
address the real underlying problems of
joblessness and weak growth in Europe
too despite the second major rescue
package to bail out being debted
countries in the ongoing crisis their
markets today think that not enough has
been done to get a handle on that
problem the attention now is focusing on
Italy and Spain where yields are rising
and markets fear that they perhaps will
not be able to pay their debts the
question now is what can we do about it
in recent weeks in the US and in Europe
we've had these two efforts they don't
seem to address the underlying problems
one option now is that maybe the US will
look at another round of quantitative
easing big injection of monetary policy
to inflate the economy we're not there
yet but the last round doesn't seem to
have worked and maybe we may be heading
towards a double-dip recession some
people think another option is
competitive devaluation some countries
Japan today Switzerland yesterday seem
to be weakening their currency and as
the kind of global economy slows some
countries might resort to weakening
their currencies at the expense of the
US economy in the US consumer
